entry.title: effective democracy takes work and is expensive
entry.content:
Research is not cheap -- there are necessarily failures required to gain knowledge. Democracy is an experiment in governance. To build insight on creation of effective government requires effort and investment.

In addition to "not investing", another option is to use signaling. Signaling is the indication of work without doing work.

Signaling would be beat by real work if there was a long-term incentive.

There are examples of signaling in nature. Frogs that aren't poisonous and merely look like an actual poison frog. In this case, the faker relies on the entity which actually does work.  If no one does work, then signaling doesn't sustain in the long term.

entry.title: balancing short-term thinking and long-term thinking
entry.content:
There's an equilibrium between
  • Tragedy of the commons: immediate benefit to me (local) outweighs cost for others in the long-term. Incentives for the individual do not align with the well-being of the group.
  • Approaches to governing a society that require immediate work and have long-term outcomes with diffuse benefits. 
Equilibrium means minimizing work needed from participants while ensuring the success of the group. "Success of the group" merely means continued existence.  

Factors relevant to determining the equilibrium:
  • size of society. For small groups, one-on-one communication is sufficient to build consensus. Past a certain threshold of group size, the ability to spend time communicating with every member drops below a temporal attention threshold.
  • perceived social norms associated with acceptable behavior
  • literacy/education of members
  • ability to communicate with other members
    • bandwidth (email versus phone versus video)
    • latency (paper letters versus email)
  • relative inequality of members in the group with respect to security, resources, ability to communicate, level of education, 
  • for the individual, how emotional (short-term) versus how analytical (long-term) is decision making 
Enumerating the factors allows us to identify options that push the equilibrium in one direction or another.

entry.title: What is the most effective approach to running a society?
entry.content:
The experiment is underway.

A state is defined by two aspects: physical boundaries and sanctioned violence. Practically, ability to enforce policy enables society.  Within this paradigm, various approaches have  arisen. No rules exist other than physics; everything else is convention.


Existence of multiple states is probably an artifact of limited bandwidth and high latency over physical distance, as well as compute and data storage limits. With increased bandwidth, decreased latency, increased compute, and increased storage the physical scale of what a state can reasonably be is increased.

suggestions: number of layers in hierarchy, terrain, insufficient resources locally, sufficient energy to interact

Is there value in partitioning physical space and having different policies enforced in distinct states? Lower efficiency, but evolution benefits from heterogeneity.

entry.title: politics is more like religion than science
entry.content:
In science we try to make falsifiable claims so that we can find evidence that our current view needs correction. The assumption is that we are seeking an explanation of reality. The mindset in science is based on curiosity: "I think this is how the world operates, so I'm going to take action that clarifies the validity of my assumptions."

In religion we assume our current perspective is the truth and then attempt to explain away all the inconsistencies.

Politics is not about seeking truth. Instead it seems to be about starting with a perspective and then fighting to implement that ideology. The mindset in politics is "I think this is how the world operates, so I'm going to take action that reinforces those assumptions."

entry.title: Disrupting OODA in the model phase
entry.content:
The OODA loop is the decision cycle of observe, orient, decide, and act. The "observe" phase is information gathering; "orient" means evaluation in comparison with an internal model.

There are many way of getting better results in a competitive environment:

  • get information faster
  • process the information faster
  • get more (relevant) information
The complication is that the model against which information is compared is not static and is impacted by incoming information. In the infinite game with low barriers to both creation of information and dissemination of information, altering your competitor's model is a powerful method of shaping outcomes. 

To alter someone's model used in the OODA process, it is helpful to understand how models are built by the individual. Much information is provided to the individual ("observe"), and then rewards and punishments are applied based on actions ("act"). The "orient" and "decide" aspects are internal to the person. This process of feedback is found in formal education -- classes, homework, tests, and grades. Once a person leaves formal education, the feedback of rewards and punishments is more diffuse and have longer time spans. 

To alter a person's model in the OODA loop, it's also helpful to prescribe a few more aspects to what constitutes a model. A model is a set of connected assumptions intended to replicate and predict reality. Each individual typically assumes there model is "knowledge" consistent with reality.  A subset of assumptions in the model are considered "conventions," implying that other individuals share the same assumptions. 

By recognizing which assumptions are conventions, we can think about why the convention exists and what the consequences could be if the convention is not adhered to. Then we can act differently from convention to generate novel information consumed by other people. These abnormal inputs then alter the other person's model. 

Not adhering to convention doesn't imply a conscious decision by the individual. Deviation from the expected norm may be based on a person's personality or experience.

"issues" are stories. A story is a sequence of logic applied to facts. What data gets transformed and what logic is applied depends on "values."

What stories unify and are emotionally resonant?

There's no demand for data since a majority of stakeholders aren't going to analyze data.

Concepts that are not measurable and either feel good or bad.

  • "rule of law"
  • "hold elected officials accountable"
  • "group X is composed of sheep"
  • "get involved""conservative/liberal values"
  • "it's not fair"
  • "the other side"


Words matter -- "opponent" casts people not in your group in a negative emotional sense.
Labels unite and divide.

We are not opposed we should be cooperating. It's not candidate versus candidate within the party, and it's not party against party, and it's not country against country. We are all humans living on earth

I used to be all about the data and the data analysis. That's necessary but not sufficient to be correct. Emotional interpretation of the story is at least as important to how people act. Just having an emotional reaction can lead people to the wrong outcome. The best case is one in which data and analysis leads to a conclusion and is supported with an emotional story.

Take the idea of government transparency. In order to know what government is doing, data is needed. Detractors argue that data collection costs money and time and therefore introduces inefficiency.

Everyone wants lower bills, right? Nope.

entry.title: alternatives
entry.content:
Suppose the electoral college were eliminated, significant improvements in campaign financing were made, and corporations were no longer considered persons. We might have a more functional democracy, but that may not be optimal. What are alternatives? (Once the alternatives are enumerated, evaluate which features could be applied in the current situation.)

Winner-take-all election outcomes drive binary political parties with an even split. Alternative: European democracies.

"One person, one vote" is strange to me -- each person is not equally knowledgeable in all domains that they are effectively voting on. Also, citizens are susceptible to emotional influence. As an alternative, amount of say on a matter should depend on amount of expertise and work contributed.

entry.title: a focus on changing laws is insufficient for long-term improvement
entry.content:
If reform is sought, what method is optimal with respect to investing time and money?

One approach to reform is to attempt to change laws governing society. For example, I think the following laws/policies would enable a fairer society:
  • non-partisian districts rather than gerrymandering
  • campaign finance reform to enable increased transparency of funding
  • better participation in voting process: everyone gets the day off, automatic registration
  • electoral college reform
  • eliminate barriers that limit current government to two parties
Regardless of which laws you think would be beneficial, it's likely that a political party representing an opposing view could come into power and reverse the law.

A distinct approach (compared to changing policy and law) is to change perceived social norms.

When I first started thinking about politics, I thought logic was the path to solutions. Then I realized emotion plays a role (see also this post and this post). Then I arrived at the observation that emotion is the core, not logic.

Now I understand that we human seek emotional stimulation. It's not clear to me what the point of logic is.

entry.title: How to define decline of the United States
entry.content:
What does a decline mean? There are many cultural and economic metrics, such as GDP, happiness index, etc. However, my way of determining is by asking "which country do a majority of non-citizens envy?" If the popular answer changes from one country to another, then the former top country has experienced a decline.

There are three possible ways forward in a given field: decline, stagnation, or improvement. Therefore, if we are stagnant and others are improving, does attention shift to where improvement is occurring?

entry.title: What makes this time unique?
entry.content:
At any given point in the history of the United States of America, events within the proceeding decade could be shown as evidence of the eminent decline. People have lived through worse times -- world wars, internment camps, economic depressions, and eugenics. What makes the current situation unique?

We have ongoing wars, undeclared military actions, torture. Struggles like the anti-Vietnam war protests (1964) and Occupy Wallstreet (2011) are a poor metric. Even domestic wars (Civil war, war of 1812) are not good indicators. Economic bubbles and depressions don't help.

What is different now compared to previous times in our history is the apathy of the population. A way of measuring this is the popularity of futurism. Is society optimistic about the future? If it were, pop culture would reflect this. Recall comics like Buck Rodgers and television shows like the Jetsons. Although not serious forecasts of the future, they indicate an optimism that the situation will improve. Science fiction as a literary genre still exists, but it is not as popular as it was for young adults. [I'm not advocating the Golden Age fallacy -- there were certainly problems facing society at any given time in the past.]

This hypothesis yields a testable claim: a rising society should have elements of futurism in the pop culture.

entry.title: the current political paradigm is more disruptive due to instability
entry.content:
Prior to 2017, my perception of politics is that there were people I agreed with and people I disagreed with. Some politicians told truths, others lied, and I accepted this as a natural state.

I was comfortable because I could use science to design experiments to validate claims. Multiple participants could make different claims, and we could determine which claims were valid by doing experiments. Although this was rarely put into practice, it was an option.

The new paradigm is what I'll refer to as "inconsistent lies." The distinction is that previously people told self-consistent lies. These claims could then be invalidated by comparing to facts collected by experiments. A mechanism existed which could drive participants to truth and therefore improvement. In contrast, self-contradiction and inconsistent lies are not suited to experiments and validation.

This isn't the first time this phenomenon has arisen in storytelling. See also inconsistencies in the bible, koran, and torah. This parallel leads to my belief that the same strategies for dealing with religious arguments may apply to the current political methods.



Conclusion 1: The distinct emotional distinction between lying and inconsistent lies is that it is no longer possible to use scientific experiments to validate or invalidate lying versus truth
Conclusion 2: Religion serves as a potential corollary example.

entry.title: what actions would be relevant for change

I view gerrymandering, campaign finance, the electoral college, and altering the judicial branch makeup to be bad. At the same time, I think taking individual action on any one issue is superficial -- it is unlikely to address underlying differences among participants.

Even if one side manages to change the law or policy, the next time the other party is in power they are motivated to undo that change. Therefore, seeking to change laws does not alter society in the long term.

This line of reasoning leads me to believe that the most effective long-term strategy for political change and societal change is to alter social norms expected by members of the society.

Changing norms rather than laws is a grandiose interest. How to accomplish this?

Using this outline as a guide, one aspect to tackle is the reasoning used in arguments. For example, gerrymandering, campaign finance, the electoral college all seem counter to representative democracy.

The underlying motivation for my actions is that I desire to live in a state that operates as a representative democracy. That's why gerrymandering and voting and campaign finance matter to me.

Next step is to take this perspective into conversation with people who disagree.

With my original view of politics as negotiation, I thought that facts, measurements, and experiments mattered in that they supported a specific conclusion.
The idea that politics is a theatrical presentation of negotiation helps explain why facts are just another tool in the actor's toolbox of available methods.

The old paradigm of lying about the facts is perfectly reasonable -- it's an alternative play put on by actors to convince the audience.

The new paradigm of lies being inconsistent is a new tactic. It's a way of driving the conversation.

entry.title: facts versus emotion in politics -- what's the basis?
entry.content:
I initially naively thought that politics was a debate using facts in order progress the country towards a better status, both locally and globally. My explanation for rhetoric (rather than logic) was that facts were being spun in order to win emotional weight of the audience.

My view has evolved. The assumption that participants start from facts does not seem to apply to politics. Instead, start with an emotional state, determine a desired outcome, then figure out how to best reach that (regardless of method).

In retrospect, the basis being emotional rather than facts and logic is consistent with the human brain. The limbic system is the core and is old; the prefrontal cortex is an add-on and is new (on an evolutionary time-scale).

This isn't a rationalization that emotions should govern politics (or any other subject).

entry.title: self, partners, friends, associates, tribe, world
entry.content:
Humans may live in large-scale societies which exceed the size of tribes we spent much of our evolutionary history in, but we still act and think using the basis of tribes.

A tribe has a set of shared assumptions, values, and goals. The people making up your tribe are your partners, friends, some coworkers, and associates you repeatedly encounter. You can exist in multiple tribes; these are more commonly referred to as social circles.

There are abstractions that are larger than tribes -- the workforce of a large corporation, a state, a large political party, nation, or fans of a popular sports team. These abstractions are meaningful in that actions result from interactions at that scale, but we humans haven't evolved with these structures.

The reason these large-scale abstractions are possible is because of communication. Prior to modern technology, the "anyone-to-many" communication was limited to shouting at a crowd (ie speeches, preaching) and posters/notices/books. One-to-one was constrained to verbal communication and writing letters; later the telegram. Crossing tribal boundaries took work and cost money.

With the advent of radio and then TV, a limited number of people were enabled to easily perform one-to-many communication across tribal boundaries. The phone allowed for one-to-one communication at a lower cost than telegrams for the same bandwidth. These modern technologies started the trend towards lower-cost communication for one-to-many and one-to-one communication.

In the past few decades, blogs and streaming video (ie YouTube) have enabled anyone-to-many communication. Review sites like Yelp provide many-to-one communication. The cost of one-to-one has plummeted with services like texting.

As cost decrease and bandwidth increases, the level of significance in the communication decreases. Less thought is invested because the cost of sending content is trivial.

Creating technology and associated infrastructure is costly. The motivation for spending money is expected profit.

As a consequence of this progress, communication across tribal boundaries is cheap.

Superficial versus principled: how did you arrive at your current opinion? Superficial = I heard a few sound bites that were persuasive, but I don't know most relevant facts.

Superficial emotional reasoning can still be passionate.

Passion manifests as anger, excitement, focus, joyousness, and obsession. Not being passionate is melancholy, anxious, and exhausted.

As a consequence of having opinions based on superficial emotions, the individual is more susceptible to rhetorical tactics.

entry.title: Vision: counteracting decline
entry.content:
Suppose the United States of America is in a decline.

Question: What would counteract the downfall?

Vision. Simply put, ask "Where do I see the world in 100 years?" If there aren't catastrophic interruptions, will the United States be a theocracy? A panopticon? How would you define your utopia?
http://youtu.be/WjVHvC9EeB4

My goals for good government are to
  1. reduce the suffering of the populace
  2. enable pursuit of happiness
Notice the phrase "life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness" captures this well. The inability to put this into practice is that it is difficult to agree how exactly to. Secondly, the populace wants government to be efficient.

In any discussion, all parties must agree upon the goals for the group, the definitions of the terms used to describe the goals, and what limits are in effect. Terms which need definition: life, liberty (freedom). "Life" is an important term as we will need to determine what it is that is being protected. "Liberty" to do what and how?

Instead of starting from a very general definition, let's start with something everyone agrees upon; a very specific case. For instance, a 43 year old working at the hardware store in town. What does "life" mean in this case? How is this person distinct from a stalk of corn?

Note that I've already tried to avoid including sex, religion, ethnicity in my example. This is because I think these aspects are irrelevant to having life. Age and the ability to do work will play a role. The reason is that a 43 year old person has already left their mother's womb and since they are working has not yet died. Since a person is not always alive, this implies two phase transitions: (1) not-born to alive, then (2) alive to dead. 

 The "easier" case of death can be defined as "heart not beating autonomically for X time." 

 The other transition, born to alive, is contentious due to the question of abortion.

entry.title: methods in rhetoric: honesty, lying, and confusion
entry.content:
Options in rhetoric: 
  • Tell the truth. 
    • factual reasoning or 
    • emotional reasoning
  • Do not use the truth
    • consistent lies
      • counter-factual reasoning or 
      • emotional reasoning
    • self-contradictory lies 
      • inconsistent counter-factual reasoning or 
      • situationally-dependent emotional reasoning
We have experience with truth (and spin), and with consistent lies. For consistent lies the response is to point out how the story differs from reality. 

The same tactic, pointing out how the story differs from reality, applied to self-contradictory lies is not productive.

One reference to the rhetorical method of self-contradictory lies is the April 2015 post
http://www.scotwork.com/negotiation-blog/2015/dead-cat-tactic

Method was also described
https://www.wnyc.org/story/trumps-reality-distortion-field/
which was aired Jan 13, 2017
The article references Putin advisor Vladislav Surkov. "Surkov turned Russian politics into a bewildering constantly changing piece of theater... It is a strategy of power that keeps any opposition constantly confused."
"Surkov has this term called "managed democracy." We maintain the right to express a preference for one policy or another but in a managed democracy, in Surkov’s view, we don't have any impact on the formation of that policy."

It's not clear to me how to address movement of the U.S. towards inverted totalitarianism.

entry.title: emotionally resonant stories
entry.content:
What's the difference between rationalization and science?

There's a difference between rationalization and hypothesis. HARKing (Hypothesizing After the Results are Known) "is defined as presenting a post hoc hypothesis (i.e., one based on or informed by one's results) in one's research report as if it were, in fact, an a priori hypotheses." More simply, rationalization tells a story about observations after the data is collected. In contrast, a scientific hypothesis is tested by carefully designing an experiment to collect data. The initial hypothesis is informed by experience (previous data).

Humans seek emotionally resonant stories to explain their environment. Rationalization takes less work than developing a hypothesis and testing it in an experiment. However, there is a long term cost to using incorrect stories that result from rationalization.
